search_parameters.q: what is the state pension age for men uk

related_questions.question: What age does a man get a pension in the UK?
related_questions.snippet: When can I claim my State Pension? The State Pension age is currently 66 years old for both men and women but will start gradually increasing again from 6 May 2026.
related_questions.title: 66 years old

related_questions.question: What is the new retirement age for men in the UK?
related_questions.snippet: The state pension age is currently 66 years old. But this is due to rise to 67 in 2026. The state pension age for both men and women will continue to rise to 68 between 2044 and 2046 for anyone born on or after 5 April 1977.
related_questions.title: 66 years old

related_questions.question: What age do I get my State Pension in England?
related_questions.snippet: Under the Pensions Act 2011, women's State Pension age will increase more quickly to 65 between April 2016 and November 2018. From December 2018 the State Pension age for both men and women will start to increase to reach 66 by October 2020.

related_questions.question: Does everyone get the same State Pension in the UK?
related_questions.snippet: The State Pension is a regular payment from the government most people can claim when they reach State Pension age. Not everyone gets the same amount. How much you get depends on your National Insurance record. For many people, the State Pension is only part of their retirement income.
